data.title: The Rose of Bokor (1969)
data.meta_description: During the occupation of Cambodia, a Japanese colonel falls in love with a French-Cambodian woman on Bokor Hill. Meanwhile, the people of Cambodia are divided between siding with their former French overlords and the new Japanese invaders.
data.text: As strong a politically ambiguous, and historically tampered piece of propaganda as it comes. King Sihanouk’s politicking includes his spiritual appeal to the masses symbolizing sex and heroism; a little shorter than thirty years into his reign, he casts himself into his own film, acting as a Japanese colonel (literally called Ichiro Hasegawa) with a wartime tenure occupying the mountaintop of Bokor; the fact he rejects an actual Japanese (even a Japanese-lookalike) but himself to play a role of a top military commander from Japan is as confusing (though unintentionally hilarious) as the film supposed to center around the romance of the titular Rose is neglected for scenes composing of slow pans across buildings/walls, reaction shots and showcases of how…
